It's a kind of lithophane; with the provided  Matlab files and ImageJ you can create a Pseudo-3D model / "lithophane"  of an image based on its intensity/gray values. (In my opinion this is not exactly a lithophane, because you don't need to lit it with a light source.)

• Import your desired RGB-image to Matlab (drag and drop).
    For example: "image2D.jpg".

  • Cluster the Image with the function "clusterImage". This function take 2 parameter: the 2D matrix of the image and the number of desired clusters. The output of the function is clustered (using kmeans algortihm) image by it's gray values.
    • For example:
    clusteredImage = clusterImage(image2D,16);

  • To create the pseudo-3D model use the function "calcPseudo3dModel". This guy takes two parameter: the cluster result of step 2 and the number of desired depth layers (this value determines the heights of your pseudo-3D model.
    For example:
    pseudo3dModel =calcPseudo3dModel(clusteredImage ,32)

  • With the function 'savePseudo3dModel' you save the created pseudo-3D model as a sequence of images. This function takes three parameters; a pseudo- 3D model, a file name and a flag. If the flag is set to 1 the 3D model or better the cluster result will be inverted and if the flag is set to 0 it won't be inverted.
    For example:
    savePseudo3dModel(pseudo3dModel, 'semih',0);

  • Import the image sequence into ImageJ and open the 3D Viewer. Select 'Display as: Surface', 'Color: White' and 'Resampling factor: 1'.

  • Export the model: File->Export surface as-> STL(binary)

  • Open the STL file with e.g. Repetier and adjust the size of the model.

This is a hanging filament holder which comes with two cones that fit in almost every spool of filament available. 
It hangs from the ceiling and is equipped with two ball bearings to ensure that the filament can move without any friction. 
Print it from any material. You will need two of both parts.

You will need
  • Two ball bearings** (inner diameter 10 mm, outer diameter 22 mm, height 7 mm)
  • A piece of threaded rod in the desired length, M10
  • Two nuts, M10
  • Two washers, M10, outer diameter 30 mm
  • Two Cable ties
  • A piece of string (any would do)
    • ** If you want to use other kinds of bearings, you will have to modify "Filamentrollenhalter Lageraufnahme.stl". I recommend using bearings that allow an easy attachment on the threaded rod. Assembly
  • Attach the Washers and the two nuts to the threaded rod. (Even if it's obvious - in the order "nut, washer, washer, nut").
  • Attach one of the bearings to each end of the threaded rod and secure them there with an appropriate glue
  • Hang the two "Filamentrollenhalter Lageraufnahme.stl" to the ceiling. Choose a greater distance than the length of the threaded rod, that makes it hang much more stable as the roll is being moved by extrusion and retraction. Use the cable ties to easily attach the string to the parts.
  • Put one of the ends of the threaded rod with the bearing on it into one of the "Filamentrollenhalter Lageraufnahme.stl". Then attach the first cone between the washers.
  • Attach the filament spool.
  • Put the other bearing into the "Filamentrollenhalter Lageraufnahme.stl".
  • Attach the second cone and screw the cones into the holes of your filament spool.
  • Adjust the fit of the cones - they should sit tight and as centered as possible to allow a smooth movement of the filament spool.
    • If the spool tends to move independently it might be spooled uneven. In this case i recommend using a rubber strap around the threaded rod and one of the "Filamentrollenhalter Lageraufnahme.stl" so the roll is breaked a little.

author: vicl

description.text:
No supports. No bridging. No retractions.
It has the astonishing property that the horizontal cross sections are simply connected and change continuously with height, so can be printed perfectly with spiral mode (or single-walled without infill). This fractal is half of the octahedron flake (or Sierpinski octahedron). Every triangular face is a Sierpinski triangle, and the base of the pyramid is (approximately) a space-filling curve called the Sierpiński curve. Figures like the Vicsek fractal also exist in this model.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

0%

Notes: Printed with the "spiralize the outer counter" option in Cura . The original scale is to match the limit of a 0.4mm nozzle..

comments.text: Thanks for sharing the link to my shop. This is not "his" design nor is it stolen. Its a mathematical model than has been made by hundreds of people, including me. Starting with Wacław Sierpiński in 1915. Claiming that this is anyone's design is like claiming that a square is somebody's design. I have made mine myself through Mathematica and have the source file in hand. You would know this if you had actually researched what the model represents instead of jumping to conclusions based on hate...

comments.text: Spiral or vase mode doesn't work for this model in Slic3r, because the model has gaps of 42 microns to enable the spiral mode print, but Slic3r fills all gaps smaller than 100 microns. It will slice, but will silently fall back to normal mode and use retractions and infill. This doesn't matter much when printing in an opaque material, but when printing in a transparent material, vase mode does produce a better-looking print. I have installed and set up Cura just to be able to print this in true spiral mode.

comments.text: In order to get this to print without retraction in Simplify3D - uncheck "retraction" on the extruder tab, on the layer tab check "corkscrew/vase" mode and set top and bottom solid layers to 0, and on the advanced tab check "merge all outlines into a solid model".  After doing this, it is printing beautifully using a single layer.  So cool to watch this thing grow!

description.text:
Hello everyone!
I´m a 13 years old spanish boy and I like technologie. I have a Prusa i3 Hephestos since Christmas and I´ve designed a few things for print them, but I´d never post nothing.
This is my first public design and I´m going to explain in what does it consist.
I designed a replacement for the original and boring transparent part you can find in a Bic pen.
With this model, students can make their own design and, later, bring it to the class and use it for writing.
Also, I dedicated the last 15 days to learn how to use OpenSCAD in order to make a customizable project. 
I hope you´ll like it!

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I recomend 0.06, but you can use other

Infill:

100%

Notes: If you´re printing with PLA, use more lacquer than normal.

First, I thought about the shape of the three avaliable models. I decided to design them with hexagonal shape, cylindrical shape and twisted hexagonal shape. The first two are easy to make, but I spent a lot of time designing the last one. HEXAGONAL MODEL
  • Create an hexagon with a hole.
    difference() {
    cylinder (r=4, h=124, $fn=100);
    translate ([0,0,2])
    cylinder (r=2.2, h=125, $fn=50);
    }
  • Create the upper part.
    translate ([0,0,124])
    difference() {
    cylinder (r1=4, r2=3.096, h=9, $fn=100);
    translate ([0,0,-0.5])
    cylinder (r=2.2, h=140,$fn=50);
    • CYLINDRICAL MODEL The same as hexagonal model, but replacing "$fn=6" by "$fn=100". TWISTED HEXAGONAL MODEL
  • Create a flat hexagon and extrude it with the twist tool. Make a hole.
    difference() {
    linear_extrude (height=124, twist=248, slices=300)
    circle (r=4, $fn=6);
    translate ([0,0,2])
    cylinder (r=2.2, h=125, $fn=50);
    }
    • 2.Create the twisted upper part. This cost me hours because I didn´t know how to design it.
    translate ([0,0,124])
    difference() {
    linear_extrude(height=9, twist=18, slices=100, scale=0.8)
    rotate ([0,0,-8])
    circle(r=4,$fn=6,scale=0.8);
    translate ([0,0,-0.5])
    cylinder (r=2.2, h=140,$fn=50);
    } ADDING TEXT
  • Download and include the Write.scad librarie.
    use <write/Write.scad>
  • Write and place the text.
    translate ([Name_size/2,-2.4,Distance_to_bottom])
    rotate([90,-90,0])
    write(Write_here_your_name, t=Font_thickness, h=Name_size, font=Font, space=Spacing);
    • FINISHED!

Objectives
  • Give people a way to personalize their pens
  • Innovate in Thingiverse
  • MY GOAL: learn how to use OpenSCAD
    • Audiences
  • Everyone how often use BIC pens
  • 3D modeling classes can use the model for learning the scale() and linear_extrude() tools
    • Preparation Students must know how to use in OpenSCAD:
  • 2D shapes
  • Translate()
  • Rotate()
  • Variables
  • Difference()
  • Union()
  • If statement
    • Step 1: Think about your design of pen You can do every design you want. You have only to keep this measures:
  • Part that keeps its same radius along its height --> 124mm
  • Part that decreases its radius along its height --> scale 1:0.8
  • Hole for the Bic --> radius = 50
    • Step 2: Design it You have to write the SCAD code in order to generate a STL Step 3: Print it and prove it Print your own model and test it by introducing a Bic inside it. If the hole hasn´t the right mesure for your printer, you can change the value and print it again
    FINISHED!

Custom model of Tony Stark's 'Mechanic Gun' from Iron Man 3. Provided as solid part and exploded with keys for printing on smaller machines. Modelled in a few hours from movie captures and the Hot Toys 1:6 accessory.
Printed with 0.2 and 0.3mm layer heights, 0.4mm walls, 10-15% infill and 3-4 top/bottom layers.
I have updated the exploded model file with better keying now that I have tested all the parts. I would recommend slicing two of the cylindrical parts (gas bottle and handle) in half in netfabb or a similar program for printing as, at least for me, the surfaces of the parts where support had been extruded came out quite rough.
This is my first model and one of my first 3D prints, if anyone has any updates they want pushed, leave a comment!

This Coin Photography Stand, or CPS, is created with the minimum focusing distance of the Sony HX90compact camera and a lot of other common compact camera's in mind. 
The camera can be placed on the top of the stand and one of the two provided coin stands can be placed in the adapter hole. The small (10mm) coin stand is for the smaller coins while the bigger coin stand (15mm) can be used for all larger coins. The adapter hole is 6mm in width to accommodate a lot of other adapters as well, if wanted.
The top hole in the stand is exactly the same size as the lens barrel of the Sony HX90v camera. This means that the camera points with the lens to the exact center of the coin. If another camera is used, place it's lens in the middel of the hole.

Notes: I use ABS for strength.
Temperature settings 225C for the nozzle and 90C for the bed.

After printing, make sure the adapter hole is exactly round and 6mm diameter. If this is not the case, the adapters won't fit. Use a 6mm drill to finish the hole perfectly. This can be done manualy, with the drill in the hand, without a machine.

Minimum focusing distance The get the biggest image on the sensor of the camera, the camera must make a photo with the subject as close as possible to the lens, this is called the minimum focusing distance. Exact centre of the lens To make the best photo of a coin, you need to make the photo at a perfect angle of 90 degrees with the center of the lens exactly above the center of the coin. Free from the background To create the best possible photo, the coin must be separated from it's background. If you lay the coin on a flat surface, there will be shadow and we don't want that. Therefore the coin is placed on a special adapter to separate it about 30mm from the background.

description.header: Project: Small Things Photography, like coins of medallions.
description.text:
Objectives The objective of this project is to learn that there are a lot of things to consider when making product shots of small things. You can use a cheap camera, but must always be aware of the physical elements such as how the light hits the object and has the ability to set the object free from it's background, what the minimum focusing distance of the used lens is, and how to get the subject as big as possible on the photo, resulting in the best picture quality. Searching for the minimum focussing distance before drawing the holder in 123Ddesign Audiences This project is great for novice photography students, as well as physics students, studying light breaking through lenses. Preparation Make sure you have the following items at hand:
  • The Coin Photography Stand
  • A Coin (preferably more coins)
  • A Compact Camera (preferably the Sony HX90)
  • A Memory card for the camera
  • A Room with enough light (near a window for example)
    • If you have a smartphone which can be connected to the camera as a smart remote, this can be handy. Though for this project it is not needed. Steps
  • Place the stand near a window so there is enough light.
  • place the camera on top of the holder with the lens mounted through the opening at the top of the holder.
  • Insert the appropriate adapter (10mm or 15mm top surface) in the mounting hole.
  • Place a coin on top of the adapter.
  • Turn the camera on.
  • If you have a smartphone to use as a remote, connect it now.
  • Set the correct values in the Manual mode of the camera. The values are: ISO 100, Aperture F/3.5, Shutter speed to suit your lighting condition.
  • With the lens all the way to the wide-angle possition, focus on the coin and make the photo.
    • Congratulations, You made the photo, but now try to explain the physics. Results Why is this photo so nice and what happens if the coin is placed without the adapter? Do you see the noticeable difference in the quality of the photo when the coin is placed on the adapter, and when it's not? Try to see what happens when you shine a little light right under the coin while maintaining the same exposure settings. Can you see you now don't have a background anymore (assuming you did print the stand in White plastic). Try looking at the results as if you are the manager of a jewelry store. Would you like to have photographs like you should have made before you knew this, or do you like it more the way you learned now? Keep this secret !!! There are a lot of tools out there in the shops to make great macro photography. You can buy stands and packshot creators for as high as 10.000 Euro's or Dollars. This coin stand is based on simple physics and costs around 3 Euro's of plastic and electricity. Use it and be sure not to say a word to your customers buying your expensive photo's of their coins :-) Enjoy !!!

author: BorisFR

title: Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro End Stop Spacers

description.text:
Update 3/13/17 I added a couple photos. Note that for the Y spacer, I also added a piece on the lever of the microswitch with shrink tubing. I had to move it farther forward to avoid hitting the clips with the fan, and shrink tube was a faster option for me. Notice also that the switch is moved to the to the farthest forward location on the frame. Time to print a new spacer, scaled to make it taller. Update 5/16/16
Added a shorter X axis end spacer to position a single extruder close to the edge of the plate. If dual extruders are used on an E3 mix nozzle base, the left one is outside the print bed. As I learned after I posted the original, the dual extruder nozzles are best handled by telling the software/firmware that they are located at -xmm and + xmm, leaving the nozzle centered and at zero when a mix extruder is attached to the machine. Note: The X axis spacer is for the metal X axis plate that supports the linear bearings and extruder holder in the current version of the Geeetech I3 Pro C printer. The Y axis piece can probably be used on other acrylic base plates. When I first got my printer running, the home position was outside the printer bed. I tried to get it working in that position, but was continually frustrated by the extruder banging against the clips that held down the glass when it started to print. I made these mechanical spacers so the Home position could be positioned close to the origin of the print bed, on or near the glass so it would avoid collisions with the clips holding the glass plate. The X axis piece is retained and stabilized by the screws on the metal X axis plate. The Y axis piece was attached to the print bed with double sided tape. The Y axis piece is a bit longer than I needed, but I moved the micro switch back a bit to make it work. It could easily be shortened by scaling in the printer controller software (Repetier in my case) or by a subtractive machining method (with a file, sandpaper or grinder).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm nozzle. 0.3 mm layer height

Infill:

not required

Notes: I printed these in PLA and they were functional. The X axis piece is more delicate, and ABS would provide more durability.
You may need a round file, or drill bit, to make the holes fit the screws.
Sketchup

I added a couple pictures that should help clarify mounting. Also, there is a bit of new text in the description. comments.text:
Just got my TFT 28 1.2, connected to AUX1 (on the unmodified MPCNC printer) and.. nada, no power . Connector position, voltage selection to 12 V for RAMPS .1.4 all checked. Measured pin 1 on the AUX1 instructions and it was giving out 5V. Hmmm, wrong instructions in the TFT manual? Set the jumper to 5V, all working! Moved my Z axis.. IT works!
Printing the frame now.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: 12V is only if you have external power. If you power it through AUX as normal, you just leave it at 5V.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: I took the plunge and bought the board. I concluded in my case since I am using the PWM pins for my filament detection implementation I can just splice the PWM pin wires from AUX 1 for that. My conclusion is based on the fact the TFT module does not use those pins for anything as TFT does not require Marlin changes and those pins are undefined in the standard Marlin implementation. I still need to keep the LCD running in parallel as my filament detection depends on the LCD to work. It should be interesting to see the printer with a "dual" LCD + TFT display. I will post results here.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: I ran my printer using Ramps DiscountController alongside this new display for a while before disconnecting the Discount display.
comments.author: 3dEz

Hi dintid,
I just saw this board on eBay for a reasonable price but could not find any commentary on user experience out there.
How is this display working for you? Any issues installing the board?

comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text:
Hello 3dEz
I am working on making a youtube about it.
Installing: 1 10-pin cable on AUX1. No firmware changes. That's it! I havn't tried it on other AUX "ports", but seing as pins are placed a tad differently you would have to rewire it some.
There are installation manual and documentation here https://github.com/makerbase-mks/MKS-TFT just enter the English folder.
I'll recommend buying directly from "Maker Base" to be sure you get the proper part. They also speak ok English.
The part itself was very nicely soldered and cleaned up, so no left over Flux or other stuff.
It's working superbly well and some machine issues I had put on Ramps seems to be gone as well: occasional print-stops.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: Sounds great! thanks for sharing. This really looks like an emerging great mod for the RepRaps as it was designed to work without any firmware mod.  I am using AUX1 (Ramps 1.4) for a filament jam monitor so I will have to figure it out how to move the monitor or the display to AUX 2. Will keep you posted.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: You cannot move it to AUX2, you must use AUX1. The MKS TFT has its own filament jam/outage input though.  It also has a power outage input so you can pick up a print if power goes out. Or you could use it for some other interrupted print feature. Refer to the datasheet for its use.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: Sputnik. Just to clarify: even if you rewire it, you can not use AUX2?
comments.author: The_Wizard

comments.text: Correct , even if you rewire it it will not work on AUX2 unless you implement software serial on one of the pins on AUX2.  I uses the same serial bus as the USB>Serial currently on board uses, which is on AUX1. Hence why no changes are needed to the firmware.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: There is an option for using an External SD as well, but I'll see if I can find time to test some external SD tomorrow.
comments.author: The_Wizard

comments.text: With regards to the serial, I tend to agree with dintid. There should be nothing wrong with serial communications, the issues I have found were completely related to the reliability of the USB to serial implementation for the Arduino (different chips in clones, need for a separate processor just to handle USB in the mega r3) plus reliability of the Virtual Serial drivers on the PC side (port access issues, etc), plus the sporadic PC interruptions due to PC performance (background processes, etc).
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: I agree for the most part , and its fine in most cases.  However I have very fast CoreXY based printers, and drip feeding over serial severely limits my quality/speed versus direct from SD , which is much faster.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text:
Sputnik77, Is there a built-in interpreter in this board, why would it have one?
Anyhow, I can see how this might (with a big might) affect throughput on a 32 Bit board (Smoothie, Due, etc) but at 115K Baud rate on a typical UART on a 16 bit Arduino mega the bottleneck will likely be the CoreXY (or Delta) calculations, hence processor board speed bottleneck, not the serial. All the TFT should be doing is reading gcode text (or bin commands) from the SD and passing it along to the serial line by line. There is a lot happening in between received gcode commands and the firmware must handle those fast enough. Also, the serial communications should be totally agnostic with regards to have binary or text gcode, again this is all handled by the Arduino firmware.
Are you running a 32 bit board?

comments.text:
Must say I rather agree with 3dEz on this on. But nice to have a talk going :)
edit: Sputnik77 define very fast? I print on UM2 clone and run at rather fast speeds now and then. Mostly below 120mm/s though (havn't recieved my Volcano block yet).
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: @3DEZ: Yes, you are correct, and I agree. It boils down to it being a corexy and the additional cycles to calculate the motion at a speed. However, I cannot change that. What I can dictate, is the source of the Gcode. On the CoreXY there is a pause at every travel move, and occasionally elsewhere when drip feeding over serial whereas direct from SD is smooth, with no pausing. I can print slower over serial to get the same quality prints , but knowing what the machine is capable of , who wants to hinder performance.

comments.text:
@Sputnik
Regarding discussion: I'm from Denmark and English is not my primary language, so just wanted to make sure you didn't take everything as statements on my part :)

comments.text: BTW. you really don't need to rebuild to get better processing speeds. Replacing your current Ardu/Ramps with Arduino Due (32bit) /Ramps FD should be as simple as reloading Marlin in the Arduino with no further modifications needed,

comments.text: Well, I have used the Due/Ramps FD on a nearly identical CoreXY build , and the problem was still present.  I think it has more to do with the implementation of the CoreXY calculations, and the ability of the buffer to keep up over serial.  The Smoothieboard/Smoothieware even has some issues with CoreXY from what I have read as well , but the info is limited.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: Sputnik77 your observation about the pauses is interesting but keep in mind though, as I mentioned before, USB serial is not exactly the same as straight serial (i.e.TFT). The USB conversion is slightly burdensome for the Arduino but there are many other factors at play in the PC side of things. Having said that, if you observed no pauses with the LCD there is really no way to compare  apples to apples without having the TFT installed. I have ordered the part today and as I mentioned in my other post I will  need to have both the LCD and the TFT installed at the same time. This should be interesting as I will be able to easily compare the gcode execution from both devices. More to come. Great conversation!

comments.text:
Again, off-topic :) but is Smoothiware multithread? I read somewhere it is not, but it could be wrong.
I am bidding on a CoreXY with a 32 bit Azteeg X5 + Smoothieware so this conversation is very timely. My goal is to test the claim CoreXY's can be faster due to stationary motors (less mass/inertia).This can be highly theoretical but it will be nice to kick the tires of a CoreXY.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text:
@3dEz my comment on multithreaded was just an analogy regarding porting Marlin, which was made for the arduino platform (8bit) to a multitude of 32bit controllers :)
CoreXY ca be faster compared to what? Faster than any prusa, sure! Faster than Ultimaker cartesian style, no.
The mass/inertia issue by having direct-extruders mounted on a moving axis is far from just theoretical. You go up by a factor 5 or so (just rough guesstimate, based on personal quick testing). Add to it a giantic moving mass of a bed for Y-axis. and you are in for bad quality compared to any CoreXY or Ultimaker style Cartesian printer (you could say Tantillus style, as I belive it was invented before Ultimaker (If I remember correctly))
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: First, we all know there is no difference between the trade-off words "fast' and "high quality" in the 3d printing world so I will just refer as "fast". The enemy of achieving fast print is mechanical positional variance, not inertia, carriage mass, geometry, processing speed  or anything like that. All of those can be, and are, at various degrees of difficulty, compensated by software (and they are).  Sure, it helps to have a good starting point for a desired "operational envelope" (i.e. for what the printer is used for).  But it is absolutely not true with regards to Ultimaker "faster than any Prusa" as long as the mechanical construction is rock solid, meaning low mechanical positional variance around the desired tolerances. There is nothing low inertia about high precision CNC routers but some of those can achieve speeds way faster than any FFF printer thanks to heavy metal solid construction.  Prusa style printers such as the TAZ 5, Wilson II's, and many others are mechanically rock solid, hence can print as "fast" as any Ultimakers. So, yes, I believe geometry advantages are only "theoretical" given so many other confounding factors. My goal of building one printer of each geometry is to understand how easy it is to squeeze speed from a geometry given a desired operational envelope (flex filaments? high mass direct drive color extrusion? very high temperature thermoplastics? etc, etc)
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: @3dEz I really don't see the relevance to the display.
comments.author: 3dEz

comments.text: Sorry I came accross this way, that was not the intention. To explain again in other words,  all you say is true about a design that reduces positional variance due to inertia, but a better measure may be comparing the final print results, at comparable print speeds. I have "non-scientifically" done that (and "that" means at least with the same filament, nozzle diameter, bed temp, etc) , and frankly there was no difference between my well calibrated and well built Prusa, with emphasis on the word "well", and an Ultimaker. Yes, I agree Prusas will not work well straight out of the box like an Ultimaker might (but, as you said, there is a price to pay in part count) but can be calibrated/upgraded well.  I do expect the results would have been different if the print characteristics were different (plastic, temp, etc), hence benefiting a specific set of design choices. There are just too many tradeoffs that will affect quality (speed) so I believe design advantages sometimes get diluted, or are significant only to specific printing needs.

author: briallison

description.text:
Show off the power of magnets with this Magnet Demonstration Tube. Simply place circular magnets in the tube with their polarities switched and watch them levitate! Note
This is just a version with a pin if you are using it with strong magnets.

I used a circle, then offset another circle. I extruded it to use as the core design. I cut out a bunch on the main tube to give it the see-through look. Lastly, I used a combination of revolved extrudes and basic extrudes to make the base. This model is far more advanced than my other ones, as it needs many reference planes to be created.
For the pin, I made a circle which I then extruded. On the top of that circle I made a smaller circle, which I extruded even longer.

Added SketchUp file. I have begun setting up my own 'ownCloud' server using a Raspberry Pi. I wanted to use a harddrive to have maximum space (currently using a large USB flash drive) but didn't want a load of wires etc. to make a mess. So I have designed this case (based on my RetroPie case) to be able to hold a harddrive internally using a USB to SATA cable. The HDD/SSD is attached to the upper half of the main case and retained using two clips. The current clips will allow for a 7mm drive but the size can be changed for different HDD/SSD thickness's. The USB lead is passed through the case, via the hole in the rear cutout and into the port on the Pi. There are now two different lower parts, one for passive use that just has slots to allow airflow, another that has an opening for a 40mm fan. I am thinking of using an SSD as the Pi may not be able to supply enough power for a HDD. Have tested the clip idea and it seems to work. The image is of a 9.5mm HDD and it is held in place quite tightly. Have uploaded an image of the top with the HDD mounted (I recycled the clips from the test piece. It is inside and I hate to waste things!). Hold really well. Using a "Sabrent USB 3.0 to SATA" adaptor, chose that as it is small and compact. Other adaptors needed to much depth. I have finished printing all of the parts and it is holding together well! Updated with some glamour photos of the final case.

Printer:

Custom - Mendel Based

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20

Parts needed Hardware
1 x Raspberry Pi B+/2/3
5 x 3mmx6mm Self Tapping Screws
2 x 2mmx6mm Self Tapping Screws
1 x Sabrent USB 3.0 to SATA Printed Parts
1 x ownCloud_Case_UPPER.stl
1 x ownCloud_Case_LOWER.stl or ownCloud_Case_LOWER_FAN.stl
2 x ownCloud_Case_CLIP_7mm.stl or ownCloud_Case_CLIP_9.5mm.stl Optional
1 x ownCloud_Case_LID.stl
1 x ownCloud_Case_INSERT.stl Fitting
  • Connect the USB/SATA cable to the harddrive.
  • Place the harddrive into the space and attach the clips into position.
  • Put the Raspberry Pi in position and attach using 2 x 2mmx6mm screws on the two mounting holes by the GPIO connector.
  • Feed the USB cable out and plug into one of the USB ports.
  • Bring the two case halves together, making sure the USB cable comes out through the hole between the case halves.
  • Insert the 5 x 3mmx6mm self tapping screws. Be careful not to over tighten the two screws that attach by the Pi or the mounting points could snap.
    • Optional
  • Inert the printed inserts into the lid (should be push fit no need for glue).
  • Glue the lid to the upper half. I used water activated Gorilla glue, seems to work well with PLA.
    • Install ownCloud I found loads of guides to help with installing ownCloud. To install ownCloud I used this site (site guides for V7 I just changed the download and extraction to 8.2.2):
    http://www.techjawab.com/2014/08/how-to-setup-owncloud-7-on-raspberry-pi.html That page makes ownCloud use SQLite which is really slow, so used this post to install and setup MYSQL: https://forum.owncloud.org/viewtopic.php?t=14964#p38141 I used this giude to setup a Dynamic DNS entry:
    http://www.htpcguides.com/nag-free-dynamic-dns-raspberry-pi/ I think that is it :) Hope this helps if you want to make your ownCloud install, so far mine is working great!

Disclaimer: No Red-eyed tree frogs named Otis were harmed in the making of this marble run. I think the power of this concept is in the timing. If you print a few pieces in advance you can spend a day or two exploring on a bulletin board or blackboard. Spend a week and change the objective each day (timing, speed, accuracy, collaboration...). Or just 'run' with it and spend two months and counting designing custom pieces and perfecting the design. A long term, multidisciplinary collaborative project. Students experience the engineering design process from start to finish. The OVERWHELMING enthusiasm from the students has been the single driving force behind the development of this project and, indeed, the creation of it. There might just be an uprising (thumbtacks and marbles O my!) if I dare interrupt this project with a quiz or test. The students have been more focused than I could have hoped. The goal of the project, simply stated, is to create a marble run that mounts entirely on a large bulletin board. The bulletin board is divided into equal sections and each student is randomly assigned to one section(after much collective practice). Students are required to create their own custom pieces that demonstrate the mechanical advantage of one of the six classical simple machines. In addition to the physical marble run students conduct experiments and create presentations about simple machines as the project progresses. They record audio presentations that discuss the design process and, of course, teach visitors about simple machines. The audio presentations are triggered by various buttons controlled by a raspberry pi. The audio box and other electronic components are being designed and built by my high school engineering class. In addition to the included pdf here is a link to the document that will update in real time as we continue to develop the project: https://www.overleaf.com/read/npmjjjgwxysb You can drag the center bar so you don't have to look at the code. If you download the PDF from the link the hyperlinks/references are clickable and will take you directly to the site. The project is in its final phase. Students are perfecting their custom pieces and the board is sectioned off so each student is responsible for their own section. Students must communicate with their neighbors in order for the entire marble run to work seamlessly.

Straight Track Section The STL included is a modular straight track section. This piece was designed in OpenSCAD using a linear extrude of a 2D outline. Track length and size of the peg hole are easily manipulated. The default is 130mm length and 7mm diameter holes to fit the VMR 6mm standard pegs. 6mm was chosen because it fits the K'nex sets we have used in class. The set of 12 takes about 9 hours to print at default speed on our flashforge creator pro. The folder with all the design files and pieces for this project has reached over 600 mb and according to our printer we have used over a mile of filament. Some notes about the variables: track_length, peg_radius and track_width are easily adjustable. Some of the other variables need to be clarified. track_radius has to do with the curvature of the track itself in creating the 2D outline for extrusion. track_height also concerns the 2D outline. You can play with the variables but proportions are not built into the script. Other pieces (all customizable) include 90 degree bend, 180 degree bend (good for reversing direction), inverted 90, inverted 180 and others types of pegs will be posted separately. The idea: Combined together you can create all kinds of curves and bends. The system is not perfect yet. The pieces will be made to interlock so that no shifting is possible. The pegs also need to be tweaked and threaded so a cap can be screwed on to hold gears and such in place.

Objectives I think every teacher would agree that the most rewarding affirmation of their hard work is the resonating sound of disappointment when the bell rings ('gong' in our case). Since we started this project (initial phases started way back in December) there have been many occasions where I have had to 'shoo' the kids out of the room so they are not late for their next class. Audiences This project is being done by the fifth grade but my twelfth grade engineering students will tell you it's fun (and challenging) for all ages. The engineering class has been following this project closely and has helped shape the rapid design of the system with their valuable feedback. Their encouragement and support should be recognized. Preparation Students should have some previous 3D modeling experience. Students in this class did the 'chess piece challenge' earlier in the year. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1374937 Phet simulations were used to introduce students to conservation of energy and balancing torques. Various mini challenges and assignments have been inserted in between phases to allow time for printing. Printing time is immense. To get started quickly look up 'VMR rapid deployment' system to use cheap PVC pipes. Materials:
  • Patience, patience, and more patience
  • Large bulletin board or magnetic surface
  • 3D printer (we have a flashforge)
  • Incredibly motivated students and supportive faculty who will tolerate marbles and thumbtacks popping up all over the building
  • Thumbtacks or pushpins (lots!)
  • Marbles (lots!)
  • Multiple storage containers (trust me)
    • Steps!
  • Take care of Otis
  • Check on the plants
  • Design
  • Test
  • Evaluate
  • Redesign
  • Rinse (aka discuss)
  • Repeat!
    • For a detailed write up please see the attached pdf or follow the link in the summary. Results I will let the students speak for themselves: *I have made no edits to these responses and the survey was optional. Thank you those who responded. How has having access to a 3D printer in school impacted your educational experience?
  • "Having a 3D printer in school has made learning science more engaging. Instead of just doing worksheets all of the period, we get to use the 3D printer and print objects that we have created on either OpenSCAD or Tinkercad and incorporate them in whatever we are learning or projects."
  • "It is helping us learn more about geometry and the challenges of making things we take for granted."
  • "Yes, in many ways because it gave science class a whole new concept."
    • Do you think hands-on projects are more effective than pad & paper learning when it comes to studying physical science?
  • "Yes, they are by far more important because we learn as we do something and that is superior. We see the results as we make them. We may fail and that is also part of learning. We may be frustrated in the beginning, but the more hand-on projects we are involved in, the better our chances to improve our learning skills and be ready for the ready for the challenges in the world."
  • "Definitely more fun and effective."
  • "Yes. I believe that when students do hands-on work, they have a greater interest in the project. The students are more likely to have a good time and learn new things when doing projects like this. I think 3D modeling is a great way to start. It can also help students to become curios about new technologies and perhaps future careers."
    • What is your opinion on the marble run project? What have you learned so far?
  • "The marble run is extremely fun to build. I am glad we're doing it. I am learning about speed and a little bit of accuracy."
  • "When I learned that my class would make a marble run, I was overjoyed. I love marble runs and wanted to get right to work. I have learned much more about 3D modeling and I am continuing to do so."
  • "I learned how to use the 3D printer better. The project is fun but I would like to do more coding on the buttons. It's a fun way to learn about simple machines."

title: Jaipnab - Just another iPod Nano (G6) Arm Bracelet

description.text:
Based on an idea i got from the MakerWatch and MacGuyvers derivative. Was not quite happy with it, so i reverse-enginered his design in my CAD-Tool and added my own style to it...
Guess it is not a 100% accurate replica (seems the old design was based on imperial units, im working only metric), so they probably can't be combined.
I had some other ideas for the design too, but this one was the first that got realized. (I might do one where the bracelet looks even more like a tank thread. I was thinking of something that looks a bit like the Leopard 2 tracks, with the two "cushions" in a row.)

Printed on an UP Mini with max. detail, max. support, 0.2mm layer in ABS.
Takes about 12 links to go around an average male wrist, depending on how thight you want it to be and how much flesh is on your bones...
The Links might be a little thight, but with some bending and working the joints it's now just where i want it to be, not to loose but still moving.
The base-plate is quite thick to fit under the iPod Nano clip, but it works and is not as loose as the ones i've found here.

Snaps onto the handle of one of these large dog retractable leashes and provides a loop  for affixing one of those little waste-bag holders, or something else.

comments.text: There is a small piece that looks like an F made of 3 mm Delrin. What is this part for and where do I put it? I cannot find anything on the WiKi related to it.

comments.text: Never mind, I just found out where it went when looking over the assembly of the dual extruder head. It goes on top of the amplifier circuit board.
comments.author: jacobhweeks

comments.text: Has anyone given this a shot with acrylic? If so what were the results?
comments.author: kscottz

comments.text: I painted it blue with acrylic and looks great! I used about 40 ml for the external case only. You should add a bit of water to the paint, so that you can paint over the logo and not obscure it too much. If I had to do it again, I would first paint a white base, though.
comments.author: kscottz

comments.text: @PabloBell, I think what she meant was, "Has anyone replaced the wood parts with acrylic parts?". @kscottz, yes someone has made one of these in acrylic. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22742http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: PabloBell

comments.text: Thanks for sharing!

comments.text: Could you please post the up to date version of the drawings? This is revision 3, but you are shipping revision 4. One of the things missing is the new 'Bertho' drive, so people have no way for instance to repair or upgrade to the current version.

author: Fboyles

description.text: I got really tired of my 2chic hair products falling over all the time in my bathroom counter (why do they make them so narrow and tall?). So I designed and printed these. If you need a custom one, contact me and I'll draw it for you.

This is a Raspberry Pi based remote rover we designed for our Explorer post project this year. It uses a Raspberry Pi 2, a cheap webcam, and a WiFi module to create a web browser controllable remote rover. The Raspbery Pi camera is also suported.
Power is supplied by an Adafruit boost/charger supply from a single LiPo cell. The Tank treads and drive system are from Tamiya. A BOM with links is included.
I would like to thank my friend Victor for all his help and inspiration on this project!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm layer height

Infill:

25%, 2 extra shells

Parts The included file parts.pdf is a list of the parts needed, along with costs and web links.
The only parts not on the list are the LiPo battery. Any battery of at least 1AH should do, and a 50mm 8ohm speaker. Assembly

  • There are assembly instructions for the gearbox in the files. I found the included instructions a bit hard to follow. The gearbox is setup for the highest ratio.

  • The chassis is built using the #2x1/2" screws. I will try to put together some instructions for that going forward, but it's pretty simple.

  • The file "Raspberry_Pi2_pinouts_v9.pdf" shows the electrical connections.between the Pi and the speed controller. The motor power comes straight from the battery. An updated doc showing the boost board and audio amp is in the works.

  • The prototype used an LM386 based amp, but Adafruit has a much better option which is listed in the BOM. It is also powered right off the battery.

  • The "TestStand.stl" file is a stand to let you run the bot motors with the treads off the ground so it stays put while your testing it.
    • Software The attached file "setup.pdf" describes the setup of the Pi. It assumes you have a micro SD card with the OS image loaded. We used Jessie lite. The software in the zip file includes ServoBlaster for running the motors as well as mjpg-streamer for supporting the webcam or a Raspberry Pi camera. The web server was modified to let it control the bot via buttons on the web page. There is also a voice menu system that uses espeak to allow you to shutdown/reboot the bot, and also get the current IP address and switch the WiFi from client mode to AP mode. All with just one button. The operation of the menu system is documented in "menuchart.pdf" In addition, text strings can be entered in the web page for the bot to say. A version of the software that runs ROS is in the works.

description.text: This is an Anchor with a hidden Mickey Twist.

Steps:
  • Print
    2, Do Something with Print

Update: 3/17/2016
Added Counterweight Suspension System for the Flying Extruder to minimize additional load on the stepper motors. This makes the whole extruder virtually weightless. Please print new_plate. This moves the suspension point at the center of gravity of the motor and is adjustable. Check out new files and video. Thanks! You will need a slightly longer bowden tube since you will raise the extruder. Get rid of the old knob and replace it with a M3x25mm screw and washer and cut a piece of rubber tubing to act as a spring to push the lever on to the filament.

Flying Extruder kit for the Kossel Mini. Can be used with any delta as well.
See video below to see it in action. I would like to give credit to WASProject of Italy for their Suspended Bowden from which I derived the design for this Flying Extruder. http://www.wasproject.it/w/bowden-sospeso-di-wasproject/﻿ The STL file included is for extruder drive gear with 6mm effective ID and 8mm OD (gear_radius=0) . Please change this value in the SCAD file if you have an MK8 drive gear (if 11mm OD, add 1.5 to gear_radius, i.e. (11-8)/2 ). DO NOT print plug.stl It is used for the SCAD file, for "tapping" a 1/8 BSPT thread. If your fitting is different, use this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:227192 to make a different plug. SCAD files are included for your customization.
(Nema 17.scad file is from Johann's Kossel Mini files) You'll need:
M3 x 16mm screws for the nipples
M3 x 35mm screw for idler adjust
M3 flat washer to insert in slot at back of extruder body
M3 nut to insert at bottom of back of extruder body (to mate with idler adjust screw)
M3 x 24mm x 3 screws for mounting motor
M3 x 12mm x 2 or similar course thread screws to fix plate to body
Clear epoxy to glue fitting to body
Bearing 16x5x5 for idler
Bolt M5 x 16mm for idler hub (A simple 5mm dia x 20mm rod will also do. I used a 5mm rivet)
3/16" ID x 100mm x 3 rubber tubing for suspending the plate to the nipples If you like it and find it useful, I'd appreciate a small tip. https://paypal.me/boksbox/1USD

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes: Use solid infill for fitting.
3 perimeters

Glue fitting to extruder body Insert the fitting into the extruder body front. Parts may need some filing to fit properly. Remove fitting from body and apply some epoxy to both mating sides. Re-insert the fitting to the body. Align the filament passage holes properly before the glue sets. I used a 2mm drill bit to make sure the holes are aligned.

title: 3Dprint a near perfect cylinder lying down

description.text:
Nothing new really but it can be a handy technique if you need support and the one offered by your slicing software isnÃÂ´t good enough.  
A cylinder is quite a good example i think, iÃÂ´ve tried many different ways (ok, standing it up doesnÃÂ´t count in this case) but it always come out rather useless.  
Of course you can add this technique to lotÃÂ´s of other shapes aswell, itÃÂ´s just an example.
Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instagram - Vimeo - LinkedIn

Open up your CAD software, draw your shape (in this case a cylinder), add support like in the pictures, BUT leave a gap between the two pieces, in this case itÃÂ´s 0,2mm but you might have to change this to play well with your printer  
Print and remove the support carefully with a knife. If there is a need for excessive force thereÃÂ´s not enough gap between the parts or the shape is to complex. Of course you canÃÂ´t have to much of a gap either...

author: barspin

description.text:
A simple endstop-holder for profile rail.
Fix your SainSmart-Enstop easily with M6 Screw.

This is Draft-E, a project I did in college. I was made aware of this project quite some time in advance so I had a lot of time to not only think about what to make, but also how I would made him. For those of you who don't know Draft-E is basically Wall-E, but his name fallows a theme from my college. The welding department made a similar Wall-E they named Weld-E, so I figured my name would be pretty funny. Anyways though please feel free to modify this how ever you wish, print it and color it how you want. My only caveat being I'd be thrilled to see what you guys come up with. Send me pictures of what you've made. I'm even open to suggestions on how to make Draft-E even cooler.

Still new to this, so please try what you please to improve. This really was my first attempt at something complex with the intention of 3D printing it, so most of it still pretty rusty. About the only thing I could really advise on would be to print his main body in two halves, that or play about with the print position. When I originally tried to print it the extruder on the Maker Bot I used kept getting clogged with just how much material there was, so I ended up having to print the body in two halves and then glue them together. Thanks to some modeling putty and a lair of paint the body pretty much looks to be in one piece. Also, I messed up a bit on some modifications I made to the arms. They were originally going to move along the tract on the side of his body, but because of concerns I had I ended up fillinga few things in, but forgot to remove the bolt holders from the body. Maybe you can salvage them and make his arms actually move. Draft-E stands at jsut over 7 1/2 inches tall. His body is also a drawer. His paint job is inspired by Johny #5

This model is from a video called "Eternal Tipping" from a channel called an0nymoose, the original character is from him.  Also, the TF2 heavy is actually suppose to have glasses but they were too thin to actually 3d print.  Hopefully 3D Printing Nerd or Barnacules could show this being 3d printed.

I used zbrush to sculpt the head, and leading to blender to add a base for the model, then leading to 123D Design to make the size right. Another thing, the 3d model might not be scaled to appropriate size it may be too small for some people.

title: Now Playing - Vinyl LP Wall Display Mounts

description.text:
I always wondered where to put the cover of the LP I was playing. It winds up sitting on the table or floor, collecting dust and not being appreciated for its art.  
This is the "Now Playing" display for your turntable rig! Two simple left and right brackets that you attach with two screws to your wall. Turn your vinyls into a constantly updated art display. Print a bunch of these pairs and cover an entire wall with easily displayed LPs!

• Print left and right brackets.
  • Measure the spacing required to fit your LPs. Have a friend mark the wall while you hold the LP and brackets in the position you want. Make sure the brackets are straight and level with one another.
  • If desired, mark holes and install plastic lugs for screws.
  • Use 4 #8 countersunk flat head screws to secure brackets to wall.
  • Test and measure to make sure your brackets are straight and can withstand the weight of your favourite 180g pressing.
  • Enjoy your new "Now Playing" dynamic album art display.

title: Wanhao Di3 backplate 80mm fan (added 60 mm fan)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this backplate to fit a 80mm fan (Noctua NF-R8) most to reduce the noise. I also change the PSU fan to a more silent fan (Spire 60mm).
I had to use a sharp knife fo cut the left side of the powerswitch so that was alinged with the edge of the backplate.
You also have to drill new hole to fasten the PSU. At least 40 mm from the original hole.
Cut off a few mm of the left and top wing"nut", either the fan will not come in place.
Happy silent printing. EDIT:
At your own risk you can skip the PSU fan and leave the PSU case open. Don't forget to mount the screw in the corner, holding the board. The 80 mm fan is enough to cool down the cabinet.

comments.text:
For people who didn't manage to fit 80mm fan in the box, just install the fan outside.... the result is the same for the extraction air flow....
Don't be stupid and don't try to push everything in that poor little box !!

author: maarten49

description.text: Confirmed Chalice from the Bitcoin Roundtable.

I came across this model on Youtube
link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3_VydFQmtZ8
and I wanted my own, so I created it in Solidworks

Printer:

dremel Ideabuilder

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1

Infill:

10%

This is a complete gearbox, with working gears.
Total lengths is 270 x 210. So its a small gearbox.
It is a model gearbox. Made in SolidWorks 2016.

Printer:

CubePro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1mm

Notes: 200x200mm minimum print bed is required.

Step 1 First you make the under part of the gearbox, you will be getting some lengths for your project, and work out the rest. Under part. Step 2 Then you can make the 2 axles and mate it into the under part.
Remember to have the measurements with tolerances, to make at tight fit. Axle 1 Axle 2 Step 3 The 2 axles have gears, bearings, note and lock rings.
The gears and bearings is a standard part you can find in toolbox. Step 4 With the upper part of the gearbox, you should be able to find all the lengths by yourself, by knowing the other parts lengths. This is a project though. Upper part. Step 5 Mate the upper part into the under part, and the gearbox is almost complete, you have to close it with 2 caps. You just build it after the parts. Cap

Gearbox project. Objectives: The students should learn how to make a simple gearbox in solidworks, using toolbox, and that you don´t need all information to make a gearbox. They will come though many features in solidworks. Audiences: This is a great fit for intermediate students at solidworks, at college level. Preparation: They should know how to operate in solidworks and know how to find parts in toolbox. They should also know what tolerances are. Steps!: Steps is shown above, but first you need to make sketch of the gearbox parts and find the missing lengths, then you need to find tolerances for every length and know what fit they should have in other parts, (tight or loose fit) Results: The result will come with technician documentation of the project, how did they find the lengths and parts. It will also include all the needed information how to make this gearbox in production.

comments.text:
Do you made it in the university?
We did nearly the same gearbox in the uni.
comments.author: Chimalis

comments.text: Yes, it was a project. But I made it from scratch.

title: Replacement Buttons for Citroen Picasso 2003 Keyfob (may fit others)

description.text:
I bought a chinese replacement fob for my car, however it required a screw-in key blade rather than the slot in plug that I have, so after melting that one to fit, I decided to replicate the missing buttons for my fob instead - I much preferred the sturdiness of the original key.
Leningrad1's Pug buttons were the correct shape, but the step was too high, and the actual button too low, so using his as a template, I modified both buttons to fit my reconditioned fob.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.01 (or any really)

Infill:

50%

Notes: I chose a higher in-fill because the buttons will be subjected to a LOT of use over time, and the 20% infill ones I first printed felt a little fragile. I also went for 4 layers top/bottom and sides to ensure a smooth print. Fitted first time!
20% infill version
